misconceptions.name: Hard-coded grade value instead of reading from user
misconceptions.description: The program never reads the numeric grade from the keyboard. It instead computes an unrelated distance between two points from user input, and then assigns a fixed constant grade (95) in code. This means the grade calculator does not respond to user-supplied grades as required by the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe it is acceptable to test the grade calculator by hard-coding a grade value in the program instead of reading the grade from the user, even though they know how to use Scanner for input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must prompt the user to enter a numeric grade (0–100) and then read that grade from the keyboard using Scanner (e.g., int grade = s.nextInt();). Any test value should come from user input, not be hard-coded in the source code.
symptoms: Program prompts for and reads x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a grade.
Program computes and prints a distance between two points, which is unrelated to the specified task.
Variable grade is assigned a constant value 95 in code and never read from input.
Changing the grade requires editing the source code, not entering a value at runtime.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely copying or reusing code from a previous distance-calculation exercise without fully adapting it to the new problem, combined with a misunderstanding that for this task the grade must be read as input rather than set as a constant.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove the point-distance code and its prompts. Instead, prompt the user for a single numeric grade (0–100) and read it with Scanner (e.g., System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = s.nextInt();). Then use that grade in your conditional logic.
related_concepts: Separating testing constants from program requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly shows Scanner being used only for coordinate inputs and the grade being hard-coded to 95 with no input read for it.

evidence.note: Scanner input is used for coordinates, not for the grade; the grade is hard-coded as 95 instead of being read from the keyboard.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Overlapping independent if statements for grade ranges
misconceptions.description: All letter-grade checks are written as separate if statements that only test lower bounds (>= thresholds). Because the conditions overlap and there is no else-if chain or upper-bound checks, some grades will produce multiple letter outputs instead of exactly one correct letter.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that writing several if(grade >= threshold) checks in sequence will automatically behave like mutually exclusive ranges (as if they were else-if), or that checking only the lower bound is enough to define each grade range.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Grade ranges must be mutually exclusive so that exactly one letter grade is printed. This can be done with an if/else-if/else ladder ordered from highest to lowest range, or by adding explicit upper bounds (e.g., grade >= 80 && grade < 90). Using multiple standalone if statements with only lower-bound checks causes higher grades to satisfy multiple conditions.
symptoms: For grade = 95, the program prints A, B, C, and D, because 95 satisfies all conditions grade >= 90, 80, 70, and 60.
For grade = 85, the program would print B, C, and D, instead of only B.
For grade = 75, the program would print C and D, instead of only C.
Only F is exclusive because it uses grade < 60, but the logic for A–D is still incorrect.
The problem statement requires mapping ranges like 90–100 to a single letter, which is violated by this overlapping logic.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how if vs. else-if works and how to define non-overlapping numeric ranges; the student likely has not internalized that multiple true if conditions will all execute unless chained with else-if or constrained with upper bounds.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The conditional structure uses only lower-bound checks and independent if statements; it is clear that a grade like 95 would satisfy multiple conditions and thus produce multiple outputs.

evidence.note: Each grade threshold is checked with a standalone if and only a lower bound, so a high grade (e.g., 95) will satisfy several conditions and cause multiple letters to print.

misconceptions.name: Task/Requirements Confusion leading to Extraneous Code
misconceptions.description: The student included a substantial block of code that calculates the distance between two points by reading four coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2). This code is unrelated to the Grade Calculator problem and violates the requirements for reading input (which should be only one numeric grade).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student included code from a previous assignment, suggesting they either forgot to remove it or tried to blend two separate programs, failing to isolate the required logic.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Programs should only contain logic pertinent to the problem statement. Input for coordinates and distance calculation must be removed.
symptoms: Unrelated output ('The distance of the two points is...')
Prompt asks for coordinates, not the grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Copy-pasting or incomplete refactoring of code from another assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always ensure your solution focuses only on the specific requirements of the current task. Clear out any unused variables or logic from past problems.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code block (L6-L11) is a complete, functioning solution to an unrelated distance formula problem.

evidence.note: Complete irrelevant code block for distance calculation.

misconceptions.name: Hard-coding Variable Instead of Dynamic Input
misconceptions.description: The student set the 'grade' variable to a fixed value (95) instead of reading the required numeric grade interactively from the user via the Scanner.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student might believe that as long as the variable is initialized, the requirement for input is fulfilled, or they may have hard-coded it for testing but forgotten to replace the hardcoded value/line with dynamic input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must wait for and read user input at runtime to fulfill the requirement of reading a numeric grade.
symptoms: Program behavior is static
Input device is not utilized for the core calculation
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to utilize the Scanner object appropriately for the required variable.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure the variable holding the grade is assigned the value received from `s.nextInt()` or `s.nextDouble()` and is not hard-coded.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Line 12 clearly hard-codes the value: `int grade=95;`.

evidence.note: Grade value is fixed at 95, not read from user.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Failure to Use Mutually Exclusive Conditional Structure (if-else if)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented the grade checking using four independent 'if' statements for the overlapping ranges (>= 90, >= 80, >= 70, >= 60). This design flaw causes the program to print multiple letter grades (A, B, C, D) for any high numeric input (e.g., 95).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that separate 'if' checks are sufficient to determine unique grade levels, possibly misunderstanding that flow control mechanisms like 'else if' or explicit compound boolean checks (`grade >= 80 && grade < 90`) are required to define mutually exclusive ranges.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When checking consecutive ranges where subsequent ranges implicitly depend on earlier ranges failing, an `if-else if-else` structure is mandatory to ensure only a single outcome is processed.
symptoms: Multiple lines of output (e.g., 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D' simultaneously)
Logic fails to distinguish between grade ranges.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the critical difference between independent 'if' statements and `if-else if` control flow.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use 'if' for the first condition and 'else if' for all subsequent conditions to ensure that once a condition is true, the rest are automatically skipped.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The pattern of four distinct 'if' statements for decreasing thresholds is a clear indicator of this common conceptual error.

evidence.note: Four independent 'if' statements for overlapping grade ranges.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using independent if statements instead of if-else-if-else chains
misconceptions.description: Student uses multiple independent if statements to check grade ranges, causing all true conditions to execute and print, rather than using if-else-if-else to ensure only one letter grade is output.
misconceptions.student_belief: Each grade range condition should be checked independently, and I should print the result for each condition that is true.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Grade ranges are mutually exclusive categories. Use if-else-if-else chains so that only ONE branch executes. Once a condition is true, subsequent branches should not be evaluated or executed.
symptoms: For grade=95, the program outputs A, B, C, and D on separate lines instead of just A
Multiple letter grades print for a single input grade
All conditions with grade >= their threshold print their corresponding letter
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of conditional statement semantics: the student believes each if statement is independent, not recognizing that for mutually exclusive categories, if-else-if-else chains are needed to ensure only one branch executes.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the independent if statements (lines 12-16) with an if-else-if-else chain. Start with the highest grade threshold (90 for A) and work downward. Use else if for lines 13-15, and plain else for line 16.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The symptom is extremely clear and consistent: for the hardcoded grade=95, all four conditions (>=90, >=80, >=70, >=60) are true and all execute independently, printing four letters instead of one. This unambiguously demonstrates the misconception about if vs. if-else-if-else structure.

evidence.note: All five conditions use independent if statements. For grade=95, all of the first four conditions are true (95>=90, 95>=80, 95>=70, 95>=60), so all four print statements execute, outputting A, B, C, and D on separate lines instead of just A.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded grade value instead of reading user input
misconceptions.description: Student hardcodes the grade value (95) instead of reading it from user input via Scanner, making the program unable to process different grade values.
misconceptions.student_belief: The grade value can be set directly in the code; I do not need to read it from user input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To satisfy the problem requirement of reading a numeric grade, the program must use Scanner to read a value from user input, not hardcode it. Only hardcoding should be used for testing, then replaced with user input for the final solution.
symptoms: Program always processes the same grade (95) regardless of user input
User input prompt is wrong (asks for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of grade)
Program cannot handle different grade values
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either forgot to replace the test/hardcoded value with actual user input, or misunderstood the requirement that the program must read the grade from the user (likely due to the wrong problem code being present first, causing confusion).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove the hardcoded int grade=95; statement. Instead, read the grade from user input using Scanner: int grade = s.nextInt(); after clearing out the wrong distance calculation code.
related_concepts: Variable initialization from user input vs. hardcoding
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly contains int grade=95; at line 11, which is a hardcoded value. This is unambiguous. The problem statement requires reading user input, and the hardcoded value prevents this.

evidence.note: Grade is hardcoded to 95 instead of being read from user input via Scanner. This prevents the program from responding to different user inputs and violates the problem requirement to read a numeric grade.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoding the grade instead of reading it from the user
misconceptions.description: The program never reads the numeric grade (0–100) from the keyboard. Instead, it reads unrelated coordinate inputs and assigns the grade as a fixed constant (95), so the user cannot supply the grade the program is supposed to convert.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe it is acceptable to set the grade directly in code (e.g., int grade = 95;) while still reading other, unrelated values from the user.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, the program must prompt the user for a numeric grade and read it from standard input (e.g., using Scanner.nextInt()), then compute and print the corresponding letter grade based on that input. Any extra, unrelated input (like x1, y1, x2, y2) should not be part of this solution.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates instead of a grade
User input does not determine the grade; output is always based on grade = 95
Behavior does not match the sample run 'Enter grade: 85' → 'Letter grade: B'
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely copied structure from a different problem (distance between two points) and did not adapt the input logic to this problem, reflecting a misunderstanding that the problem requires reading the grade itself rather than any numeric input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove the coordinate-related prompts and variables. Prompt the user with 'Enter grade: ' and use Scanner to read an int (or double) into the grade variable, e.g., int grade = s.nextInt(); then base all conditional checks on this input.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly reads four doubles labeled as coordinates and then hardcodes int grade = 95; without any attempt to read a grade value, which directly contradicts the problem statement and sample run.

evidence.note: The program reads four doubles labeled as coordinates, then hardcodes grade to 95 instead of reading a numeric grade from the user as required.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using independent if statements with overlapping grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The student uses multiple independent if statements that each test only a lower bound (>=) on the grade. For a high grade like 95, several conditions are true simultaneously, causing multiple letter grades (A, B, C, D) to be printed instead of exactly one.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that checking each threshold with a separate if (grade >= X) is sufficient to select one letter grade, perhaps assuming only the 'best' one will effectively count.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, each if condition is evaluated independently, and all true conditions execute. To ensure exactly one letter grade is printed, conditions must be mutually exclusive—either by using an if–else if–else chain, or by giving each if both lower and upper bounds (e.g., grade >= 80 && grade <= 89) so that only one condition can be true for any given grade.
symptoms: For grade = 95, the program will print A, B, C, and D each on a separate line
Ranges are not bounded above; A covers 90–100 but B also covers 80–100, C covers 70–100, etc.
Fails the requirement that one letter grade correspond to each numeric grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how if statements execute and how to express non-overlapping Boolean ranges. The student is checking thresholds but not considering that multiple conditions can be true at the same time if they are written as separate if statements with only lower bounds.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the structure to an if–else if–else chain, e.g., if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } ... else { ... }, or explicitly include upper bounds in each if so that the grade falls into exactly one interval.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The conditions are written with only lower bounds using separate if statements, which is a textbook pattern for overlapping ranges; for the given hardcoded grade of 95, four different branches are clearly true.

evidence.note: Each grade band is checked with an independent if using only a lower bound, so high grades satisfy multiple conditions and cause multiple letters to be printed.

misconceptions.name: Unrelated input reading
misconceptions.description: The student reads input for two coordinate pairs (x1, y1, x2, y2) which is completely unrelated to the Grade Calculator task, and then ignores this input for the actual grading logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to be reusing or copying code from a previous assignment (likely a distance calculator) without removing the irrelevant parts, or they may mistakenly believe this input is necessary.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should only prompt for and read a single numeric grade (0-100).
symptoms: Program prompts for 'x1 and y1' and 'x2 and y2'
Reads four double inputs using `s.nextDouble()`
Calculates distance (d) which is never used for grading
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to correctly address the problem specifications (Program Scope Misunderstanding) combined with copy-pasting irrelevant code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove all code related to distance calculation and coordinate input. Only prompt for and read the single 'grade' value needed for this task.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly reads four doubles and calculates distance, which is entirely outside the scope of the assignment.

evidence.note: Reads unrelated input and calculates distance formula.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoding input value
misconceptions.description: The student declares and initializes the variable `grade` to 95, ignoring the input previously read (even though that input was irrelevant anyway). The program will always output the grade for 95.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student might believe that reading the input and hardcoding a test value are equivalent, or they failed to replace the hardcoded test value with the actual input variable.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The variable `grade` must be assigned the value read from the user after the prompt.
symptoms: The output is always 'A' followed by 'B', 'C', and 'D' (if not fixed by the next misconception). Since 95 is used, the grade logic executes regardless of user input.
misconceptions.root_cause: Oversight in connecting the input logic to the processing logic; failure to follow the requirement to use user input dynamically.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: If you intended to read the grade, remove the constant assignment `grade=95` and replace the extraneous input reading with proper reading for a single grade. Example: `int grade = s.nextInt();`
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Line 9 explicitly sets `int grade=95;`, overriding any chance of using dynamic input.

evidence.note: The grade is hardcoded to 95 instead of being read from the relevant input.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Non-exclusive conditional logic (IF instead of IF-ELSE IF)
misconceptions.description: The student uses a series of independent `if` statements instead of `if-else if` blocks. When a grade meets a high threshold (e.g., 95), it satisfies *all* subsequent lower thresholds (90, 80, 70, 60), causing the program to print multiple letter grades (A, B, C, D) simultaneously.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that meeting a condition (like `grade >= 90`) automatically prevents checking or printing subsequent results, or they misunderstand how grade ranges work in programming logic.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To ensure mutual exclusivity of ranges, conditional logic must use `if-else if` structures. For instance, once 'A' is determined (`grade >= 90`), lower grades (B, C, D) should not be checked.
symptoms:
For a grade of 95, the output is 'A
B
C
D'
For a grade of 85, the output is 'B\nC\nD'
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how cascading conditions are evaluated; confusion between independent checks and mutually exclusive categories.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the subsequent `if` statements to `else if` statements to ensure that only the highest matching grade is printed.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code uses five independent `if` statements clearly demonstrating this structural error.

evidence.note: All conditions are independent 'if' statements, leading to multiple outputs for high grades.

misconceptions.name: Wrong input variables and wrong problem code
misconceptions.description: Student reads x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a grade, implementing code for a completely different problem (distance calculator). Then hardcodes grade=95 instead of using actual input.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied code from a wrong problem without checking what the current problem asks for.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The grade calculator problem requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) from the user using Scanner.nextInt() or Scanner.nextDouble(), and then processing only that value.
symptoms: Program asks for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a grade
Final grade is hardcoded to 95 instead of using user input
The calculation reads two coordinate pairs and computes Euclidean distance (from a different problem)
misconceptions.root_cause: Student likely copy-pasted code from a different problem or previous assignment without verifying it matches the current problem requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace lines 4-10 entirely with: System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = s.nextInt(); Delete the hardcoded grade=95.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The evidence is unambiguous: the code explicitly reads x1, y1, x2, y2 and calculates distance, which is a different problem entirely. Then hardcodes grade=95. This is 100% wrong for the stated problem.

evidence.note: This entire section is code for calculating distance between two points—a completely different problem. Should be reading a single grade instead.
Grade is hardcoded to 95 instead of being read from the user input. Makes the program non-interactive and violates problem requirements.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Sequential if statements instead of if-else-if (overlapping conditions)
misconceptions.description: Student uses five independent sequential if statements with overlapping conditions instead of an if-else-if chain. This causes multiple letter grades to print for a single input grade. For example, grade=95 prints A, B, C, D instead of just A.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that once an if condition is satisfied and its body executes, subsequent if statements automatically know to exclude that range and will not execute. Or the student does not understand that each sequential if condition is checked independently.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, sequential if statements are independent. Each condition is evaluated and its body executes if the condition is true, regardless of whether previous if statements executed. To ensure only one branch executes, use if-else-if chains: if(...) { ... } else if(...) { ... } else if(...) { ... } else { ... }. Alternatively, add upper and lower bounds to each condition: if(grade >= 90 && grade <= 100) for A.
symptoms: Program outputs multiple letter grades (A, B, C, D) for a single input instead of exactly one
Grade of 95 produces A, B, C, D on separate lines
Grade of 75 would produce C, D on separate lines
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how sequential if statements work. Student likely thought that checking one range would automatically skip the others, or did not test the code with sample input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the five separate if statements with an if-else-if chain: if(grade >= 90) { System.out.println("A"); } else if(grade >= 80) { System.out.println("B"); } else if(grade >= 70) { System.out.println("C"); } else if(grade >= 60) { System.out.println("D"); } else { System.out.println("F"); }
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly contains five separate if statements with incrementally weaker conditions (>=90, >=80, >=70, >=60, <60). These overlap for any grade >= 90. Testing with grade=95 would immediately reveal this bug: it prints A, B, C, D instead of just A.

evidence.note: Five sequential if statements with overlapping conditions. For grade=95: all of if(grade>=90), if(grade>=80), if(grade>=70), and if(grade>=60) evaluate to true, so A, B, C, D all print. Should use if-else-if to ensure only one executes.
